bestBHT.bht: Let her alone, for she has done a good work on me. This act of anointing was not only good in itself, but it was also particularly timely. In addition, the fact that she gave what she could made it even more acceptable to Jesus. Therefore, it is best to cease reproving her for what she has done.

Henry Alford: 6.] Let her alone, also common to John, but as addressed to Judas.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: she hath wrought a good work on me—It was good in itself, and so was acceptable to Christ
it was eminently seasonable, and so more acceptable still
it was 'what she could,' and so most acceptable of all
Philip Schaff: Mark 14:6. Let her alone (so John, but addressed in the singular to Judas). The rest of the verse corresponds with Matthew.
John Gill: Let her alone, cease to chide and reprove her for what she has done.

bhtAttempts.bht: Let her alone, for she has done a good work on me. This act of anointing was not only good in itself, but it was also particularly timely. In addition, the fact that she gave what she could made it even more acceptable to Jesus. Therefore, it is best to cease reproving her for what she has done.

In this verse, Jesus tells Judas to leave the woman alone. The commentators note that what she did was a good work, and therefore acceptable to Christ. It was not only good in itself, but also done at the right time. Moreover, it was done with what she had, making it even more acceptable. In essence, Jesus is telling Judas to stop reproving her for her actions.

Jesus' response to Judas is to let the woman be, for she has done a commendable act. It is not only good, but timely and fitting. In fact, it is the best she could do given her circumstances. The message here is clear: there is no need for Judas to criticize or rebuke her for what she has done.

Jesus responds to those questioning the woman's actions, saying, Let her alone. This is a common phrase used by Jesus, but in this instance, it is directed specifically at Judas. The first-tier commentator highlights three reasons why the woman's actions were good and acceptable to Jesus. Firstly, her action was good in itself. Secondly, it was the right time for this act of devotion. And finally, it was a demonstration of her offering all that she could to Jesus. By using the phrase Let her alone, Jesus is instructing others to cease their criticism and acknowledge the significance of the woman's gesture.

Jesus responds to those questioning the woman's actions, saying, Let her alone. This phrase, also found in the book of John, is directed at Judas. The woman's act is considered good and acceptable as it was timely, demonstrating her devotion to Jesus. It is commendable because she offered all that she could. When Jesus says, Let her alone, He implies that others should stop reproving her for what she has done and recognize the value of her gesture.
